trait.name: Abortion pattern
trait.description: Describes the stage at which pollen grains abort in male sterile lines.

method.name: Abortion pattern estimation
method.description: Collect florets and fix in 3:1 Acetic acid:alcohol solution. Squeeze out pollen grains under a drop of acetocarmine stain, observe under a microscope at 10x10 magnification, and estimate the predominant staining behavior and number of nuclei visible

categories: 1= Pollen free (TGMS line, e.g. Norin PL12)
3= Abortion at uni-nucleate stage of pollen (CMS-WA type)
5= Abortion at binucleate stage of pollen (CMS-HL type)
7= Abortion at trinucleate stage of pollen (CMS-boro type)
9= Abortion at later stage: pollen grains look like fertile pollen (518A cytoplasm from O. nivara)

trait.name: Alkali injury
trait.description: The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected in alkaline soils

method.name: Alkali injury assessment
method.description: Observe growth in alkaline soil in relation to standard resistant and susceptible checks. Since some soil problems are very heterogenous in the field, several replications may be needed to obtain reliable scores.

categories: 3= Growth nearly normal but there is some reduction in tillering and some leaves discolored
5= Growth and tillering reduced, most leaves discolored, only a few elongating
7= Growth completely ceases, mostleaves dry, some plants dying
9= Almost all plants dead or dying

result.contextOfUse: Evaluation - black leaf streak disease and other leaf spots

trait.name: Black leaf streak disease severity
trait.description: An indication of the extent of damage on an individual leaf caused by black leaf streak disease.
trait.synonyms: Black Sigatoka disease severity, Percentage area necrotic

method.name: Black leaf streak disease severity - estimation
method.description: Visually observe and record the amount of the surface area of a standing leaf that is affected by black leaf streak disease.

scale.name: Faures stages of development of BLS disease scale (1987)

categories: 1 = Stage 1 appears as a small depigmentation spot whose whitish or yellow colour resembles stage 1 of Yellow Sigatoka disease. These symptoms are not visible in transmitted light and can be observed only on the underside of the leaf.

2 = Stage 2 appears as a stripe, generally brown in colour and visible on the underside of the leaf, later the symptom also appears on the upper part of the limb as a stripe, the yellow colour of which resembles the stripe at stage 1 of Yellow Sigatoka. The colour of this stripe will change progressively from brown and later to black on the upper side of the limb, but will retain the brown colour on the underside.
3 = Stage 3 differs from the previous one by its dimensions. The stripe becomes longer, is enlarged and in certain conditions (weak inoculum and unfavourable climatic conditions) can reach 2 or 3 cm.
4 = Stage 4 appears on the underside as a brown spot and on the upper side as a black spot.
5 = Stage 5 is when the elliptical spot is totally black and has spread to the underside of the limb. It is surrounded by a yellow halo with the centre beginning to flatten out.

6 = Stage 6 is when the centre of the spot dries out, turns clear gray and is surrounded by a well-defined black ring, which is, in turn, surrounded by a bright yellow halo. These spots remain visible after the leaf has dried out because the ring persists.

result.contextOfUse: Evaluation - black leaf streak disease and other leaf spots

trait.name: Black leaf streak disease severity
trait.description: An indication of the extent of damage on an individual leaf caused by black leaf streak disease.
trait.synonyms: Black Sigatoka disease severity, Percentage area necrotic

method.name: Black leaf streak disease severity - estimation
method.description: Visually observe and record the amount of the surface area of a standing leaf that is affected by black leaf streak disease.

categories: 1 = Initial speck stage: faint, minute, reddish-brown specks on the lower surface of the leaf.
2 = First streak stage: specks elongate, becoming slightly wider to form narrow reddish-brown streaks.
3 = Second-streak stage: streaks change colour from reddish brown to dark brown or black, sometimes with a purplish tinge, clearly visible at the upper surface of the leaf.
4 = First-spot stage: the streaks broaden and become more or less fusiform or elliptical in outline and a water soaked border appears around each lesion.
5 = Second-spot stage: the dark brown or black centre of each lesion becomes slightly depressed and water soaked border becomes more pronounced.

6 = Third or mature spot stage: the centres of the lesions dry out becoming light grey or buff coloured and a bright yellow transitional zone appears between them and the normal green colour of the leaf. The lesions remain clearly visible after the leaf has collapsed or withered because of their light coloured centre and dark border.

result.name: BlkLfStrkSvrt_Est_MedLawCpt
result.contextOfUse: Evaluation - black leaf streak disease and other leaf spots
result.growthStage: Monthly, from 3 months after planting until harvest, and including at the Date of shooting and at the Date of harvest

trait.name: Black leaf streak disease severity
trait.description: An indication of the extent of damage on an individual leaf caused by black leaf streak disease.
trait.synonyms: Black Sigatoka disease severity, Percentage area necrotic

method.name: Black leaf streak disease severity - estimation
method.description: Visually observe and record the amount of the surface area of a standing leaf that is affected by black leaf streak disease.

categories: 1 = Initial speck stage: symptoms are first visible to the naked eye as faint, minute (less than 0.25 mm diam), reddish brown specks on the lower surface of the leaf. Specks are often most abundant near the margin of the left side of the leaf, particularly towards the tip. Where leaf spot is severe, specks have been observed on the second leaf of plants that have not yet produced a bunch. Elsewhere they usually appear on the third, fourth, or older leaves.

2 = First streak stage: the initial speck elongates, becoming slightly wider, to form a characteristic narrow, reddish brown streak up to 20 mm long and 2.0 mm wide, with the long axis parallel to the leaf venation. At this stage, streaks are more clearly visible on the lower surface of the leaf than on the upper one. The distribution of streaks is variable. Sometimes they are most numerous near the edge of the left side of the leaf. At other times they are equally numerous on both sides of the leaf, and more or less evenly distributed. Frequently they are densely aggregated in a band several cm wide on one side or both sides of the mid-rib, becoming less numerous towards the edge of the leaf. Streaks may be so numerous that every cm2 of leaf surface bears one or more. There is considerable variation in the length of individual streaks on a given leaf, and they frequently overlap to form larger, compound streaks.

3 = Second-streak stage: the streaks may elongate slightly, but the most notable change is that in colour from reddish brown to dark brown or almost black, sometimes with a purplish tinge. The streak is now clearly visible on the upper surface of the leaf. The distribution of streaks at this stage of development varies in the same way as mentioned above. When streaks are very numerous, and more or less evenly distributed, the entire leaf blackens.

4 = First-spot stage: the streak broadens and becomes more or less fusiform and elliptical in outline and similar to the first-spot stage of Sigatoka (Leach 1946). The transition from streak to spot is further characterised by the development of a light brown, water-soaked border around the spot. This water-soaked effect is especially clear in the early morning, when dew is still present on the leaf, or after rain.

5 = Second-spot stage: the dark brown or black central area of the spot becomes slightly depressed and the water-soaked border becomes more pronounced due to darkening. At this stage, a slight yellowing of the leaf tissue immediately surrounding the water-soaked border may occur.

6 = Third or mature spot stage: the centre of the spot dries out, becoming light grey or buff-coloured, and further depressed. The spot is surrounded by a narrow, well-defined, dark brown or black border. between the latter and the normal green colour of the leaf, there is often a bright yellow transitional zone. After the leaf has collapsed and withered, spots remain clearly visible because of the light-coloured centre and dark border.

trait.name: Index of non-spotted leaves
trait.description: An index to express the proportion of standing leaves without the typical late-stage symptoms of black leaf streak disease, i.e. a black spot with a necrotic centre. This index provides an estimation of available photosynthetic leaf area prior to fruit filling and is a measure of resistance. It also corrects for the difference in the number of leaves produced by different types of bananas.

method.name: Index of non-spotted leaves - computation
method.description: Calculate as: 100 multiplied by (Youngest leaf spotted, minus 1), divided by Number of standing leaves, e.g. 100 * (6 - 1) / 12 = 42.
method.formula: index of non spotted leaves with black sigatoka at flowering: YLS -Youngest leaf from the top showing at least 10 spots with necrotic/dry center. INSL- The proportion of standing leaves without the typical late-stage symptoms of black Sigatoka. INSL = 100 * (YLS ? 1)/ NSL.

trait.name: Seedling vigor
trait.description: Biomass of the plants in the plot at 15 days after sowing

method.name: Seedling vigor - Method
method.description: Comparative visual observation of the biomass of plants (length, width, number of leaves) 15 days after sowing. The maximum score is given to the plot that has plants with maximum biomass. The lowest score is assigned to the plot with the minimum biomass. Plots with biomass between these two extremes will be included notes between the two extreme scores.
method.reference: House, L.R. 1987. A guide to sorghum breeding. Second edition. Patancheru, AP 502 324, India: International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics.

The maximum score is given to the plot that has plants with maximum biomass. The lowest score is assigned to the plot with the minimum biomass. Plots with biomass between these two extremes will be scored between the two extreme scores.

method.description: Compute DSI for each genotype using the formula: DSI = (1 – Yds/Yns)/DII, where DII is the drought intensity index, Yds and Yns are mean yields of a given genotype in drought stress and no stress environments, respectevely.

trait.name: Anthracnose resistance
trait.description: Degree of resistance to Anthracnose disease. Causative organism: Colletotrichum truncatum. Symptoms develop when plants start to flower. Necrotic lesions can be found on the lower leaflets and cause premature leaf senescence. Symptoms can also be found on stem starting from the base to the top of the plant

method.name: Scoring method for Anthracnose resistance
method.description: Quantification of symptoms development in leaves and stem

categories: 5=Few deep lesions, mostly superficial, no stem girdling
7= Several deep stem lesions, mixture of deep and superficial, partial wilting
9=Deep penetrating lesions coalesce, stem girdling, wilting

trait.name: Aphid resistance
trait.description: Degree of resistance to Aphids. Acrythosiphon pisum. Suck sap from tender parts of plants and it is the vector of viral diseases.

method.name: Screening method for Aphid Resitance
method.description: Infestation area was taken and the percentage of area infestated was determined at seven days interval
method.reference: Journal of Agriculture and Rural Development,4(1&2),101-106.

trait.name: Ascochyta blight resistance
trait.description: Degree of resistance to Ascochyta blight . Causative agent: Ascochyta lentis (Didymella lentis). The pathogen infects leaves, stems, petioles, pods and seeds. On leaves, young lesions with small necrotic spots of 3-5mm diameter can be found. Reddish brown to black pycnidia from in the middle of the mature lesions. In severe infections, lesions gridle the stem, kill the epidermal and cortical cells and lead to stem breakage. Pods can also be infected and results seed infection. Heavily infected seeds look shrivelled and discoloured with a whitish mycelium and pycnidia.

method.name: Visual estimation of Ascochyta blight Resistance
method.description: Quantification of infestation rate in leaves and stem

categories: 3=small flecks or small lesions on leaves and chlorosis at leaf tips
5=Many leaf lesions, leaf drop, stem flecks or small lesions
9= stem girdling and or plant death

method.description: Count the number of plants on linear sections defined in each sowing line at the exception of the border lines
method.formula: PlantStand = (Total nb of plants counted) / (Ls x Nc x E). Where Ls = length of a linear section in m (1 m or more when plant density is variable within a plot), Nc = nb of sowing lines chosen for plant counting, E = inter-line spacing.

trait.name: Plot coverage
trait.description: Percentage of the plot covered, 1 = poor to 7 = good establishment

trait.name: Plot population homogeneity
trait.description: Judgment of homogeneity of the accession, 1 = homogeneous to 7 = mixed

categories: 1: Most plants are the same (up to 10% different)
3: Over half of plants are the same (10%–30% different)
5: Less than half of plants are the same (30%–50% different)
7: Over 50% of the plants are different, completely mixed plot; will need to be excluded from analysis

trait.name: Plant branchiness
trait.description: Score for the overall amount of side branches of representative plants in a plot, ignoring very small and spindly branches, ranging from 1 = no branches to 7 = bushy plant with many major lateral branches

categories: 1: Low number or no secondary branches
3: Some branches (30 – 50% of the primary branch length has secondary branching)
5: Branched (50 – 70% of the primary branch length has secondary branching)
7: Highly branched (above 70% of the primary branch length has secondary branching)

trait.name: Plant growth habit
trait.description: Four categories of growth habit described in images on the scoring card. Here the focus lies on whether branching is present from the base of the plant and if a main inflorescence can be identified

categories: 1: Not branched at base, usually with a clearly defined terminal panicle
3: Some branching from the base; no significant panicles on branches in the basal area (thus, this is not worth harvesting)
5: Branching from the base with more significant panicles
7: Main panicle is difficult to identify

trait.name: Stem breakage incidence
trait.description: Stems are broken or detached, assessing the percentage of the plot affected

trait.name: Stem lying incidence
trait.description: Stem of the plant is not emerging straight up from the soil but has a kink at the base, growing along the ground before rising; assessing the percentage of the plot affected

trait.name: Stem lodging incidence
trait.description: Plants are prostrate, on or near the ground, with intact stems; assessing the percentage of the plot affected

trait.name: Stem angle
trait.description: The angle at which the majority of plants are leaning, measured between the vertical axis and the horizontal axis

categories: 1 < 22.5° inclination or deviation of the stem from the vertical (i.e. most plants are upright)
7< 90° (i.e. most plants are on or very close to the ground)

trait.name: Panicle axis angle
trait.description: The angle at which the majority of panicle axes are leaning, measured between an upright panicle on the verticle and a panicle pointing towards the ground

categories: 1< 45° inclination or deviation of the panicle from the vertical (i.e. most panicles are upright)
7< 180° (i.e. most panicles are pointing towards the ground)

trait.name: Plant height
trait.description: Height of the most representative plants of the plot, usually from the middle of the plot, measured with a long measuring stick from soil to the tip of the panicle. If more than one distinct phenotype is present, more than one plant may be recorded in a new row of the spreadsheet, with all phenotypes that are differing recorded separately

trait.name: Canopy height
trait.description: The height of a plant, plot, or group of plants when measured from the soil surface to the growing apex or average growing apex of the plant(s).

method.name: Plant natural height measurement
method.description:
Description: Measure the natural height of plants

 Materials: metric ruler/tape measure

 Dependent_on:

 Protocol:
 1. For a single plant, place the origin of the ruler at the base of the plant on the surface of the soil.
 2. Record the vertical distance to the growing apices of the plant or the average height of the plant if the growing apices are lower than the tallest points of the plant (i.e. when the growth habit is not erect).
 3. Repeat for as many plants as necessary and average the results for the entire plot, group.

trait.name: Flower fertilization
trait.description: The percentage of flowers on a raceme or group of racemes that were fertilized and developed into legume fruit.

method.name: Flower percent fertilization computation
method.description:
Description: Record the percentage of flowers that were fertilized on a raceme.

 Materials: loupe (if needed)

 Dependent_on: Legume fruit cnt [n], Flower number cnt [n]

 Protocol:
 1. Sample racemes according to your sampling protocol.
 2. Record the flower number on each raceme
 3. Record the fruit number on each raceme
 4. For each raceme, divide the fruit number by the flower number to get a percentage of flowers fertilized.
 5. For more than one raceme, record the average percent fertilization as a percentage

trait.name: Forage ADF content
trait.description: The total forage fiber content as determined by the acid detergent fiber method.

method.name: Acid detergent fiber measurement
method.description:
Description: Measurement of acid detergent fiber with acid detergent solution

 Materials: See protocol

 Dependent_on:

 Protocol:
 1. See https://uwlab.soils.wisc.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/17/2015/09/forage_ADF.pdf
method.formula:
ADF = frac{(W0 - Wt)*(100)}{S}


 W0 = mass of dried crucible with fiber
 Wt = tared mass of dried, empty crucible.
 S = oven-dry sample weight

trait.name: Forage ash content
trait.description: The total ash content

method.name: Forage ash content measurement
method.description:
Description: Determine the ash content of a sample of forage

 Materials: muffle furnace; porcelain crucibles; laboratory balance;

 Dependent_on:

 Protocol:
 1. Sample forage according to your sampling protocol.
 2. Weigh crucible and record weight to 4 decimal places.
 3. Weigh approximately 2 g into crucible.
 4. Record weight to 4 decimal places.
 5. Ash sample at 600oC for 2 h. (Bring temperature rapidly to 600)
 6. Cool in desiccator and weigh within 1 h after reaching room temperature.
 7. Weigh ashed sample and record weight to 4 decimal places.
 8. Calculate % Ash and record value with one decimal.
 9. https://www.clemson.edu/public/regulatory/ag-srvc-lab/feed-forage/procedure20.html

method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

scale.name: 1-9 FRSHAPE RB scale
scale.xref: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Calyx position
trait.description: The position of the calyx attachment relative to the fruit shoulder.

method.name: Calyx position 1-5 method
method.description: Observe and rate the average positon of the calyx attachment relative to the shoulder of the fruit on 3-5 fruit per genotype.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Percentage of viable achenes
trait.description: The percentage of achenes that are viable.

method.name: Percentage of viable  achenes method
method.description: Observe and estimate the percentage of viable/filled achenes in 10% increments on 3-5 fruit per genotype.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Fruit flesh firmness
trait.description: The firmness of fruit flesh.

method.name: Fruit firmness method
method.description: Compress a fully ripe fruit between thumb and forefinger and rate the average firmness of flesh on 3-5 fruit per genotype.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Skin toughness
trait.description: The toughness of skin.

method.name: Skin toughness method
method.description: Estimate the average skin toughness by dragging the thumb firmly over the skin on 3-5 fruit per genotype.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Skin color
trait.description: Skin color on the sun side of a fully ripe fruit.

method.name: Skin color 1-9 method
method.description: Observe and rate the average fruit skin color once to twice weekly for when fruit color is fully developed and 30-50% of the fruit on the plant are ripe.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

scale.name: 1-9 SKINCOL scale
scale.xref: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Skin gloss
trait.description: The glossiness of skin.

method.name: Skin gloss method
method.description: Observe and rate average fruit skin gloss on 3-5 fruit per genotype.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Fruit flesh color
trait.description: The color of fruit flesh.

method.name: Fruit flesh color method
method.description: Observe and rate the average fruit flesh color on 3-5 fruit per genotype.
method.reference: Mathey, M. M., et al. (2013). J Am Pomol Soc 67(4): 205-217.

trait.name: Anthracnose resistance
trait.description: The plant resistance to Colletotrichum trifolii measured on young plants in controlled conditions

method.name: Anthracnose resistance - Computation
method.description: Assess the resistance to clover rot using a bio-test in controlled conditions, rate it from immune/resistant to susceptible, and calculate the resistance index
method.reference: Frey et al. (2023) Phenotypic variation and quantitative trait loci for resistance to southern anthracnose and clover rot in red clover

trait.name: Beginning of flowering
trait.description: Time when flowering starts

method.name: Begin of flowering time - Measurement
method.description: Record date when the first flowers appear in the plot
method.reference: Jing and Boelt (2021) Seed Production of Red Clover (Trifolium pratense L.) under Danish Field Conditions.

trait.name: Beginning of flowering
trait.description: Time when flowering starts

method.name: Begin of flowering time - Computation
method.description: Compute number of days required from sowing (in dryland areas use first day of rainfall or irrigation) to when the first flowers appear in the plot
method.reference: Jing and Boelt (2021) Seed Production of Red Clover (Trifolium pratense L.) under Danish Field Conditions.

trait.name: Clover content
trait.description: Percentage of red clover herbage in field plots with companion grasses and/or grassland herbs

method.name: Clover content - Computation
method.description: Separate clover herbage and determine the weight fraction compared to the total herbage

trait.name: Clover rot resistance
trait.description: The plant resistance to clover rot caused by Sclerotinia spp. measured on young plants in controlled conditions

method.name: Clover rot resistance - Computation
method.description: Assess the resistance to clover rot using a bio-test in controlled conditions, rate it from immune/resistant to susceptible, and calculate the resistance index
method.reference: Frey et al. (2023) Phenotypic variation and quantitative trait loci for resistance to southern anthracnose and clover rot in red clover

trait.name: Dry matter content
trait.description: Dry matter content (%) of herbage harvested in field plots

method.name: dry matter content - Computation
method.description: Determined by weighing a freshly harvested sample, drying it at 60°C for 48h, and weighing the dried sample

trait.name: Dry matter yield
trait.description: Dry matter yield of herbage harvested in field plots

method.name: Dry matter yield - Computation
method.description: Dry matter yield harvested in a field plot, calculated from the fresh matter yield and the dry matter content

trait.name: End of flowering
trait.description: Time when flowering ends

method.name: End of flowering time - Measurement
method.description: Record date when no more new flowers are formed in the plot
method.reference: Jing and Boelt (2021) Seed Production of Red Clover (Trifolium pratense L.) under Danish Field Conditions.

trait.name: End of flowering
trait.description: Time when flowering ends

method.name: End of flowering time - Computation
method.description: Compute number of days required from sowing (in dryland areas use first day of rainfall or irrigation) to when no more new flowers are formed in the plot
method.reference: Jing and Boelt (2021) Seed Production of Red Clover (Trifolium pratense L.) under Danish Field Conditions.

trait.name: Floret fertility
trait.description: Fertility of individual florets, measured in controlled environment with pollinators

method.name: Floret fertility - Counting
method.description: Register the number of seed per floret
